content.p: While Sooda is quite a new technology, it's already been given some serious testing. It is currently used as a Data Access Layer technology for Atmo - a workflow-building technology created by the company I work for and has been deployed in a number of projects.

The following tables summarize the current status of Sooda. Some areas obviously need more serious testing before they can be called production-ready. I don't have time or equipment to do all the testing myself, so If you'd like to help us improve Sooda by providing testing and support for one of the following areas, join the development team.

tr.td: It's not recommended to use Sooda with .NET 1.0. It may not even compile on this platform. Use .NET 1.1 instead
this is the primary development environment of Sooda
.NET 2.0-specific features like partial classes and nullable types aren't supported yet. Otherwise everything should work unmodified on .NET 2.0 (modulo some warnings during the compilation)
unit tests mostly pass, due to some limitations of the platform some features (in particular separate stub compilation) aren't supported and will probably never be.
this is the main RDBMS we use while developing Sooda
some basic features tested on Linux/Mono with Npgsql driver
basic features tested on Windows with Npgsql driver
there's support for Oracle join syntax, completely untested
trivial things (insert, update, delete) should work, in complex SOQL queries Sooda relies on subqueries and they aren't supported in MySQL3
basic features tested on Linux/Mono with ByteFX driver
